Key Facts
Distance from Sun
Recorded By

Nutrients
Mercury is the closest planet to the Sun at a distance of 57 million kilometers.
Venus is the second planet from the Sun, and the sixth-largest planet in the Solar System.
Earth is the third planet from the Sun and our home planet.
Mars is the fourth planet from the Sun and the second-smallest planet of the Solar System.
Saturn is the sixth planet from the Sun with the largest planetary rings in the Solar System.
Jupiter is the fifth planet from the Sun and the biggest planet of our Solar System.
Uranus is the seventh planet from the Sun, and the third-largest planet in the Solar System.
Neptune is the farthest planet from the Sun at an average distance of 4.5 billion kilometers.
Assyrian astronomers in 14th Century BC.
Babylonian astronomers in 14th Century BC.
Scientists have researched and estimated that our Earth is around 4.5 billion years old.
Egyptian astronomers in 2nd Millennium BC
Assyrians in 8th Century BC.
Babylonian astronomers in 7th or 8th Century BC.
William Herschel in March 13th 1781.
Urbain Jean Joseph Le Verrier & Johann Galle in September 23rd 1846.
Despite being so small, Mercury is the second-densest planet in the Solar System after Earth.
Mercury does not have any satellites or ring systems.
Though it is the closest planet to the Sun, temperatures on Mercury are both hot and cold.
Mercury spins around slowly compared to Earth. One day on Mercury is 59 Earth days.
Almost 85% of Mercury’s radius is represented by its enormous iron core.
Venus is the second brightest object in the sky after the Moon, and the Sun.
It is the only planet named after a female deity and the brightest planet in the Solar System.
The highest mountain on Venus, Maxwell Montes, is 20,000 feet very similar to the highest mountain on Earth, Everest.
Venus is very similar to Earth, and because of this, it is referred to as Earth’s sister.
One day on Venus lasts for about 243 Earth days.
The surface of Earth is covered by water, around 71%, only 29% of Earth’s surface is covered by land.
Earth has the greatest density out of all the planets in our Solar System.
Earth has only one satellite, the Moon, but it also has a couple of temporal artificial satellites.
The name Earth is at least 1.000 years old.
Earth formed at around the same time as the rest of our Solar System.
The first person to observe Mars with the use of a telescope was Galileo Galilei in 1610.
Light from the Sun reaches Mars in about 13 minutes.
Mars is the most widely searched planet for life, inspiring many works of fiction.
Mars has two known natural satellites, Phobos and Deimos.
Mars does not have a magnetic field however some areas are highly magnetized.
Saturn is the King of the Moons, having a total of 82 confirmed moons. There are probably more out there.
The largest moon of Saturn is named Triton, and it is the second-largest moon in the Solar System after Jupiter’s moon Ganymede.
Saturn does not have a solid surface. It is enveloped by swirling gases and liquids the further down you go.
Saturn has the lowest density of all the planets. It is lighter than water and if placed on it, the planet would float.
Periodic storms are present on Saturn and they are large enough to be seen from Earth. They are named White Spots.
Uranus rotates in the opposite direction than most planets, from East to West.
Uranus has the coldest planetary atmosphere in the Solar System with temperatures around -224 degrees Celsius.
Uranus has 13 known rings surrounding it but they are difficult to observe.
The reason why Uranus is blue is due to the presence of methane.
Uranus has been visited only once by a spacecraft, namely, Voyager 2.
Wind speeds on Neptune are among the fastest recorded in the Solar System. Some may reach up to 2.160 km.
Neptune’s color is believed to be influenced by the presence of methane in its atmosphere.
Neptune is the first planet to be discovered by the use of mathematical calculations and predictions.
Neptune has a powerful magnetic field. It is 27 times stronger than Earth’s.
Many believe that it was closer to the Sun then than now, but the planet started to drift away.
The envelope of gas atmosphere surrounding Jupiter is the largest planetary atmosphere in the Solar System.
Jupiter also has 3 ring systems but much smaller than Saturn’s.
Jupiter experiences 200 times more asteroid and comet impacts than Earth.
Jupiter’s mass is almost twice of all the Solar System’s planets combined. It is 318 times more massive than Earth.
Jupiter is the Solar System’s vacuum cleaner, because of its powerful gravity which attracts many of the comets and asteroids to hit it rather than other planets.
Panthera leo
Panthera tigris
Panthera pardus
Hippopotamus amphibius
Sus scrofa domesticus
Oryctolagus cuniculus
Elephas maximus
Giraffa camelopardalis
Ursus Arctos Horriblis
Ailuropoda melanoleuca
The biggest lion ever recorded weighed 827 pounds. This lion was almost 10 feet long in length.
The biggest tiger ever recorded weighed more than 900 pounds. Siberian Tigers are the biggest tiger breed in the world.
The largest leopard,the Persian leopard is the largest leopard subspecies.
The largest hippo recorded was a male hippo that weighed to be 4.5 tons (9000 lbs). It was about 45 years old.
The world record for the heaviest pig so far is held by Big Bill, owned by Elias Buford Butler of Jackson, Tennessee. It scales at 1,157 kg in 1933.
The world\'s largest rabbit is the German gray giant. This breed of rabbit weighs well over 23 pounds and is huge.
The largest elephant ever recorded was shot in Angola in 1955. The Height of this largest elephant from ground to withers, 13 feet 2 inches.
The tallest giraffe now is Zulu. Zulu the giraffe stands at just over 19 feet tall.
Kodiak bears are the largest brown bear, comparable in size to polar bears.
The largest panda in the recorded history is has the size of 120–150 cm.
African lions have been admired throughout history for as symbols of courage and strength.
Asiatic lions are a subspecies of African lion, but only one very small population survives in India\'s Gir Forest.
Lions are the only cats that live in groups, which are called prides—though there is one population of solitary lions.
Female lions are the pride\'s primary hunters and leaders.
Adult male only stays in the pride for about two years before they are kicked out by competitors.
There were eight tiger subspecies at one time, but three became extinct during the 20th century.
Bengal tigers live in India and are sometimes called Indian tigers.
A hungry tiger can eat as much as 60 pounds in one night, though they usually eat less.
Females give birth to litters of two to six cubs, which they raise with little or no help from the male.
Average life span is about 8 to 10 years.
The leopard is so strong and comfortable in trees that it often hauls its kills into the branches.
Leopards are strong swimmers and very much at home in the water, where they sometimes eat fish or crabs.
Most leopards are light colored with distinctive dark spots that are called rosettes, because they resemble the shape of a rose.
Leopards can also hunt from trees, where their spotted coats allow them to blend with the leaves until they spring with a deadly pounce.
Cubs live with their mothers for about two years otherwise, leopards are solitary animals.
They typically live in forests and are excellent tree climbers, but are also found in mountains and swamps.
Black bears are very opportunistic eaters.
When winter arrives, black bears spend the season dormant in their dens, feeding on body fat.
Female black bears give birth to two or three blind, helpless cubs in mid-winter and nurse them in the den until spring, when all emerge in search of food.
Despite their name, black bears can be blue-gray or blue-black, brown, cinnamon, or even (very rarely) white.
It takes 28 pounds of bamboo to satisfy a giant panda\'s daily dietary needs.
They may climb as high as 13,000 feet to feed on higher slopes in the summer season.
Pandas are often seen eating in a relaxed sitting posture, with their hind legs stretched out before them.
Pandas will sometimes eat birds or rodents as well.
A typical animal eats half the day—a full 12 out of every 24 hours—and relieves itself dozens of times a day.
Pigs are highly intelligent and easily trainable animals, learning various tricks even faster than dogs.
Hippopotamus are distant relatives of pigs.
During a long period of time, China used to hold the largest population of domestic pigs around the world.
Pigs in general are very afraid of being taken up.
When walking, these animals use only 2 toes of each foot, due to which they seem to walk on tip toe.
Rabbits can be very crafty and quick. To get away from a predator, a cottontail rabbit will run in a zigzag pattern and reach speeds of up to 18 mph (29 km/h).
Their ears can grow to 4 inches (10 cm).
Their eyes are made for safety, too, since each eye can rotate 360 degrees.
Rabbits are very social creatures and live in large groups called colonies.
Wild rabbits create their own homes by tunneling into the ground. These tunnel systems are called warrens and include rooms for nesting and sleeping.
Hippopotamuses love water, which is why the Greeks named them the “river horse.”
Hippos spend up to 16 hours a day submerged in rivers and lakes to keep their massive bodies cool under the hot African sun.
If threatened on land hippos may run for the water—they can match a human\'s speed for short distances.
Each female has only one calf every two years.
They may travel 6 miles in a night, along single-file pathways, to consume some 80 pounds of grass.
The trunk alone contains about 100,000 different muscles.
Asian elephants have a finger like feature on the end of their trunk that they can use to grab small items.
An adult elephant can consume up to 300 pounds of food in a single day.
Most illegal ivory today comes from African elephants, with some 30,000 poached each year.
The Asian elephant is classified as Endangered by the International Union for the Conservation of Nature (IUCN).
A giraffe\'s legs alone are taller than many humans—about 6 feet.
The 21-inch tongue helps them pluck tasty morsels from branches.
Giraffes only need to drink once every several days.
Giraffes have beautiful spotted coats. While no two individuals have exactly the same pattern, giraffes from the same area appear similar.
Giraffes to run as fast as 35 miles an hour over short distances and cruise comfortably at 10 miles an hour over longer distances.

Brassica oleracea
Capsicum
Daucus carota
Solanum tuberosum
Lycopersicon esculentum
Brassica rapa var
Solanum melongena
Zea mays
Allium cepa
Beetroots are a great source of fiber, folate (vitamin B9), manganese, potassium, iron, and vitamin C.
Cabbage is an excellent source of vitamin-K and vitamin-C.
It contains antioxidants like beta carotene (carotenoid), lutein and zeaxanthin (phytochemicals) and vitamin C.
According to recent research, falcarinol, a compound present in carrots, is largely responsible for the reduced risk of lung and colon cancer.
Potato is rich in vitamin B6 which aids in building and repairing body cells.
A single tomato can provide you with 40% of the daily dose of Vitamin C.
Turnip is rich source of dietary fibers, vitamins C and potassium.
Eggplant is a very good source of dietary fiber, vitamin B1 and copper. It is a good source of manganese, vitamin B6, niacin, potassium, folate and vitamin K.
Corn contains lutein and zeaxanthin, the forms of vitamin A that are especially beneficial for eye health.
Onions are filled with complex sugars that keep our metabolism healthy, vitamins, minerals, dietary fiber, beta carotene, folate (one of the B vitamins), and they have no fat.
Turnip is a type of root vegetables that belongs to the mustard family.
Fruit of turnip is seedpod filled with numerous miniature seed.
Turnip was staple food in the Ancient Greece and Rome.
Turnip was massively consumed in Germany during the WWI when meat and potato became scarce.
Turnip is biennial plant, which means that it completes its life cycle in two years.
On average, each person on the planet eats 73 pounds of potato each year.
Blue potato is a variety of potato that originates from South America. Skin and flesh of this potato are purple, but they become blue after cooking.
Potato is the first plant that was launched and successfully grown inside the space shuttle in 1995.
Potato is perennial plant, which means that it can survive more than two years in the wild.
Marie Antoinette and Louis XVI used flowers of potato in decorative purposes.
Smallest tomatoes have 0.4 to 0.8 inches, large tomatoes have 4 inches.
Fruit of tomato is called berry.
Stem, leaves and green (unripe) fruit contain alkaloid called tomatine which can induce poisoning.
Ripe tomato is safe and highly recommended piece of fruit because it contains high level of mineral and vitamins.
Greatest producer of tomato in the world is China.
Carrots originate from Afghanistan. First types of carrots were purple and white in color.
Longest ever recorded carrot had 17 feet in length, while the heaviest carrot had almost 19 pounds of weight.
Edible part of carrot is the root. It reaches maturity 70 to 100 days after planting.
Too many carrots in diet may lead to orange skin especially on the palms and soles. This condition is known as carotenosis.
Unlike other vegetables, carrots are rich in sugar.
Some varieties of eggplant produce white, lavender, green or red-striped fruit that can be elongated, rounded or pea-shaped.
Eggplant requires high temperature (it grows during the summer) for proper growth and development.
Eggplant is known as "crazy apple" in Italy due to widespread belief that diet rich in eggplants leads to madness.
It originates from China.
Name "eggplant" originates from 18th century when cultivars with small, white fruit, shaped like hen\'s egg were popular.
Onion releases sulfur during the process of slicing which creates sulfuric acid in combination with moisture from the eyes which induces eyes to produce tears to eliminate it.
Onion was worshiped in the ancient Egypt.
Onion was even used as currency along with parsley and garlic.
Onion was used as strength-booster during the Olympic Games in Greece in the 1st century AD.
Crushed onion can be used for polishing of silverware and other metal objects.
corn is used as biofuel, in the manufacture of numerous chemical products and fabrics.
Each cob of corn consists of usually 600 kernels that are arranged in 16 rows.
North America is the biggest producer of the corn in the world.
One acre of corn eliminates 8 tons of carbon dioxide from the air.
Besides selective breeding, new varieties of corn are produced via genetic engineering.
Eating raw beets or drinking beet juice helps combat garlic breath.
In 1975, Soviet cosmonauts gave American astronauts borscht, or beet soup, as a symbol of camaraderie. They jokingly pasted vodka labels over the tubes of pink soup.
Albert Einstein famously hated beets.
Many cultures believe that if a man and woman eat from the same beetroot, they will fall in love.
Ancient Assyrian texts reveal that beets grew in the legendary Hanging Gardens of Babylon in 800 BC.
Flowering cabbages are grown for ornamental purposes.
Most popular cultivars of cabbage are savoy, spring greens, green, red and white cabbage.
Latest studies showed that cabbage can prevent development of certain types of cancer.
China is the greatest manufacturer of cabbage, while Russia consumes the greatest amount of cabbage in the world.
Cabbage is one of the oldest cultivated vegetables in Europe.
It was Christopher Columbus who collected capsicums from the West Indian regions in the 1492 and took them to Spain.
In 2005, a poll of 2,000 people revealed peppers to be Britain\'s 4th favorite culinary vegetable.
Red capsicums, compared to green, orange and yellow ones, are the sweetest.
The oldest found capsicum was discovered in the remains of pottery from Puebla and Oaxaca, today’s Federal Districts of Mexico.
The misleading name “pepper” (pimiento in Spanish) was given by Christopher Columbus upon bringing the plant back to Europe.
